qas.question: What was one of the first times the Supreme Court tried a case regarding nondelegation?
In what year was Wayman v. Southard tried by the U.S. Supreme Court?
Who was Chief Justice of the Supreme Court when Wayman v. Southard reached the Supreme Court?
In Wayman v. Southard, what branch was accused of being given lawmaking abilities by Congress?
What is the name of the 1825 case where the supreme court held that congress could delegate their responsibilities to the court?
Who was chief justice of the supreme court under the Wayman v. Southard ruling?

plausible_answers.text: Where Congress does not make great and sweeping delegations of its authority

qas.question: Where has the Supreme Court been known to be more stringent towards Congress?
What is one of the most recent races regarding limits of non delegation?
When did the Supreme Court hear John Marshall v Southard?
Which case was heard by Congress in regards to non delegation limits?
When was the US Congress Court Wayman v. Southard heard?

context: <b6_0>Where Congress does not make great and sweeping delegations of its authority<b6_0/>, the Supreme Court has been less stringent. One of the earliest cases involving the exact limits of non-delegation was <a0_0><a4_0><b7_0><b9_0>Wayman v. Southard<b9_0/><b7_0/><a4_0/><a0_0/> 23 U.S. (10 Wet.) 1, 42 (<a1_0><b8_0><b10_0>1825<b10_0/><b8_0/><a1_0/>). Congress had delegated to the courts the power to prescribe judicial procedure; it was contended that Congress had thereby unconstitutionally clothed <a3_0>the judiciary<a3_0/> with legislative powers. While Chief Justice <a2_0><a5_0>John Marshall<a5_0/><a2_0/> conceded that the determination of rules of procedure was a legislative function, he distinguished between "important" subjects and mere details. Marshall wrote that "a general provision may be made, and power given to those who are to act under such general provisions, to fill up the details."
